The Egyptian Gazette
The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1888.
Editor and Manager R. Shellin.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, JANUARY 29. 1906.
LORD CROMER’S SPEECH.
The most interesting portion of Lord
Cromer's speech on Saturday last, on the occa-
sion of the opening of the Nile-Red Sea
Railway, was the statement as to the general
and local policy of the British Government
in Egypt and the Sudan. This statement
consists of two propositions, one of which is
that the existing régime will, go on as it now
does whether Lord Cromer does or does not
remain at the helm, while the other is that
the Government at home, whatever other
line of policy it may adopt elsewhere, will
not interfere in Egypt. In this article we
will discuss the bearings of the former of
there two important announcements. That
they are of importance nobody will venture
to deny, and their importance is rendered ex-
traordinarily signifiant by the manner in
which they have been interpolated into
the speech. Lord Cromer is a master of English
prose and he has so nicely dovetailed these
statements with the rest of his speech that
at the first glance it would appear that their
entry is becoming and can in no sense of the
word be regarded as an intrusion. But a
careful review of the speech will show that
they form a deliberate climax to which the
jreoeding words carefully lead up to, while the
remaining portion of the address is only an
equally careful descent to the formal announce-
ment of the opening of the railway. Evidently
Lord Cromer considered that the time had
come to officially answer the question which
many have been thinking—will not the deli
cately poised arch of English rule in Egypt lose
its keystone with the departure of Lord
Cromer. He himself answers that it will not,
and added that when he did depart, “all that
need be said would be, ’ll n’y a qu’un Anglais
de moins’.”
It would, of course, be absurd to consider
that any Englishman, however eminent he may
be, is indispensable to the Empire. When the
most preponderating personality in the state-
craft of the world was unexpectedly given
notice that his services Were no longer needed,
Europe was surprised to see how things went
on in just the same sort of way as before
after Bismarck's withdrawal from the great
stage of international politics. Why, then,
should not Egypt pursue the same course as
heretofore even it Lord Cromer no longer be
at the helm? But Egypt is quite abnormal, as
a greater master-builder of Empire than even
Lord Cromer long ago saw, when be found
it necessary to incorporate this country
into the Roman Empire on a principle
entirely contrary to that which elsewhere
dominated the State. In the present day,
just as in the time of Augnstus, Egypt
is still abnormal, and the enlightened
absolutism of the present régime, with
all its curious paraphernalia of make believe,
is so successful that when the Japanese
surveyed the world to find a model for tbs
Government of their new conquest they an-
nounce that they have chosen the Egyptian
system whereon to base their administration of
Korea. But, however successful may be the
existing system of Egyptian rule, it most be
remembered that it has only been built up
within the space of a few years, and the whole
structure rests on a very fragile foundation.
The equipoise is rendered still more delicate by
the tendency towards centralisation, which is
irresistible in such a personal system of go-
vernment, and year by year the administrative
machine is apparently made thereby to run
smoother and smoother. A striking example
of this centripetal tendency is seen in the
endeavours of the Government to remove the
headquarters of the Quarantine Board to
Cairo, and in such cases, ‘Tappetit vient en
mangeant.” Observers have noticed the danger,
for it is easy to see that this concentrated sys-
tem of government, however well it may Work
in Lord Cromer’s hands, can as easily be made
to run in one direction as another. An intelligent
writer on the Egypt of to-day has remarked —
“-One thing is certain, and that is that the
financiers and speculators are to-day in Egypt
a formidable force to reckon with. Lord
Cromer, who has a horror of everything in
the nature of a gamble and who sees dearly
the danger which threatens his work, has, un-
fortanately rather late in the day, dipped
their wings. As long as he holds the reins
he will apply the brake which will keep Egypt
safely and surely from the mad rush which
would lead to a crash such as the world has
never yet seen—whilst he is there—yes, but
when he is gone? That is the question which
many thoughtful men are asking to-day, and
they naturally fear that through political and
other influences a man of less experience may
be given the place so brilliantly filled by Lord
Cromer, when the day comes for him to ex-
change for a well-earned rest the field of
battle and of progress on which he has covered
himself with glory.”
Lord Cromer on Saturday went out of his way
to state that be intends to remain here “as
long as my health and strength endure" and
that when he departs all that need be said will
be “Il n’y a qu'un Anglais de moins.” But this
seif-depreciation is a “petitio principii,” for it
is the one Englishman that will make all the
difference when the time comes for him to go,
as it is impossible to believe that when the day
comes for Lord Cromer to hand over the reins
of government the régime will be exactly the
same. But whatever may be the alternative,
the most dangerous is that of a capitalistic
Cabal, which in the opinion of many serious
observers of the signs of the times is to be the
Final, just as Lord Cromer is the Efficient,
Cause of the prosperous Egypt of to-day. Mean-
while we must be thankful with Lord Cromer’s
announcement which he formally made that
he will stay in Egypt as long as he possibly
can, and we are sure all our readers of every
nationality will be equally pleased to know
that such is Lord Cromer’s determination.

To day the Government gains are seven and the Unionist one. The Government undergoes no change in sixteen constituencies and the Unionist in six. Mr. Walter Long has been elected.

Mr. Haldane, speaking at Edinburgh, laid stress on the fact that what we want in the army is more "thinking” officers in the cavalry and line regiments. He looks to the universities to suppiy these. Commenting on the magnificent majority gained by the Government, and the power it conveyed, he said that what they wanted was ideas.

div.head: Mariout Diatrict.
div.p: Miralai Hopkins en Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, left yesterday for a five days’ inspection of the Mariout district

div.head: Stray Dogs.
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Ein Shams district of Cairo at dawn to morrow, 'and in Abbassieh at dawn on Wednesday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: A New Departure.
div.p: Messrs. Gilliam and Walters, representing the British American Tobacco Co., Limited, Cecil Chambers, London, have engaged premi- ses in Cairo and will shortly start work.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: Two sacks of hashish were seized by the Coast Guards on Saturday night as they were being drawn through the water towards the coast at Gabbari by means of ropes from some ship in the harbour. The would-be smugglers escaped.

div.head: The Weather.
div.p: A fairly strong gale prevailed yesterday and on Saturday night at Alexandria, and a high sea ruled. The Coast Guard Nesseem was caught in the gale off the coast on Saturday night and had one of her boats carried away, besides her bowsprit She had to put in to Aboukir for shelter.

div.head: The Kaiser’s Birthday.
div.p: Saturday being the 47th anniversary of the Emperor William’s birthday many buildings in Cairo flew the German flag. A service was held in the German Church at 10 a.m. at which Dr. Rucker Jenisch, Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General; Dr. Gumprecht, Consul; and all the staff of the Agency and Consulate were present. A reception was held at the Agency and later in the morning Dr. Rucker Jenisch called on Boutros Pacha Ghali, Minis ter for Foreign Affairs, who returned the call shortly afterwards. In the evening a grand tanquet was held at the Continental Hotel at which over a hundred members of the German Colony were present.

div.head: Egyptian Directories.
div.p: The directories of Mr. Stefano G. Poffandi and of Messrs. Rizzo and Co. for 1906 have made their appearance. Considering the great difficulties That have to be encountered in this country in keeping a directory up to date and ferreting out all the changes of address, estab- lishments of new firms and companies, and the hundred and one other odds and ends that go to make up a reliable work of the kind, we must say that these two works are excellent. With the exception of the G unison Directory, which is only a partial one, there are no other works of the kind in Egypt, and both Mr. Poffandi and Messrs. Rizzo & Co.’s books deserve to be on the desk of every business man in Egypt.

div.head: DEATH OF SIR E. PALMER.
PROMINENT LOCAL FINANCIER.
SKETCH OF SUCCESSFUL CAREER.
MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA.
div.p: The Gymkhaua to be held at Mena House Hotel on Tuesday, 6th February, promises to be a great success. Officials from the country who are taking advantage of the Beyram holidays are beginning to send in their ponies to Mena House Hotel, whose management have made special arrangements to provide stalls for that purpose. In order to enable residents to take part in the donkey races the manage- ment have also made arrangements to keep a large number of donkeys on the race course which can be hired there at the rate of 5 piastres a-boad. The bookings for the ladies’ horse race (distance three furlongs) are coming in fast, and the two hack races for gentle- men are likely to be well patronized. The band of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers has been engaged and an excellent tea will be served on the ground free of charge. Lieut. Col. Hill has kindly consented to act as judge, and if the weather is as fine as it is now, there is no doubt that half Cairo will be out at Mena House to see the fun. The Tramway Company has arranged for an extra service that day. Cars will run from Kasr-el-Nil tramway station evary 15 minutes. We regret to announce that Sir Elwin Palmer died yesterday morning at 6 15 o’clook at his residence at Cairo. In the first week of December, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer left fora trip to Khartoum, where Miss Palmer had preceded them, Sir Elwin being desirous of seeing something of Mr. Leigh Hunt’s development work at the Atbara. On return- ing to Cairo he appeared to be ill and it was believed that he was suffering from a touch of sun-stroke. Bat it was soon recognised that the malady was enteric fever. It was thought that it was only a mild case and to all appearance ho w a so soon on the way to recovery that we were able to announce on the 10th inst. that he was making rapid progress towards convalescence and he could even see a few visitors. Two days afterward it was stated that he was so well that he hoped to be able to return to work in a few days’ time. But in enteric no patient can be considered out of danger until his convales- csnce is complete, for a relapse may even be worse than the primary fever, as was the case with Sir Elwin. Early last week he became rapidly worse and bulletins were posted daily on the door of his home at the National Bank. On Wednesday the doctors reported that the invalid had passed an easier night, on Thurs- day the news was not so comforting, Dr. Hess and Dr. Wildt, who were in attendance, reporting that he had somewhat lost strength, bat Friday’s bulletin showed that he had passed a better night and that his temperature had come down. On Saturday we stated that he had passed a bad night and that his heart had become weaker, and yesterday morning the end came. Sir Elwin was born on the 3rd March, 1852 and was therefore in his fifty-third year. He was the son of Mr. Edward Palmer and of Caroline, the daughter of Colonel Gonthorpe. He was educated at Lancing College and entered the Indian Financial Department in 1871. In 1881 he married Mary, the daughter of Major Herbert M. Clogstoun, V. C. He to be badly India until 1885, when he was appointed to accend Sir Gerald Fitzgerald as Director General of Appoints in Egypt. It is thanks to Sir Gerald Fitzgerald and Sir Edwin Palmer that Egypt p system of accounts which can bear companies with those of any other country in Europe. It is quite possible for the finances of a country to be badly administered, whilst, at the same time, the accounts may be in good order. On the other hand, it is impossible for the statesman or financier to seriously commence the work of fiscal and adminis- trative reform until, by the organisation of proper system of accounts, he is placed in possession of the true facts connected with the resources and expenditure of the State. One of the principal reasons why the early attempts made to regulate the financial condition of Egypt failed, was that the ac- counts were in a state of the utmost confu- sion. Owing to the efforts of Sir Elwin and his predecessor the Egyptian Accounts Department was thoroughly well organised and it would be difficult to exaggerate the importance of this achievement. In the summer of 1889 Sir Edgar Vincent resigned the post of Fi- nancial Adviser to the Egyptian Government to go to Constantinople as the Governor of the Imperial Ottoman Bank and Sir Elwin Palmer was appointed to succeed him in what was then and is still the corner-stone of English influence inside the Egyptian Ad- ministration. Sir Edgar Vincent left Egypt too soon to see the complete vindication of his financial policy, for during the six years of his administration he had been vigorously attacked as a juggler, who bad no real genius for grappling with the difficulties of finance, but only great skill in avoiding them. But Sir Elwin prudently and ably continued Sir Edgar’s system of administration, which has since then produced such brilliant results. In 1897 Sir Elwin was made a K. C. B. and in 1892 K.C.M.G. In September, 1898, he re- igned his position as Financial Adviser and Sir Eldon Gorst succeeded him. It is curious to note that the late Sir Clinton Dawkins severed his connection with the Finance Ministry almost at the same time as did Sir Elwin and both have died within a few months of one an other. The reason of Sir Elwin’s retirement from the service of the Egyptian Government was because he was appointed Governor of the National Bank of Egypt, which had been founded in that year. Previous to his retire- ment the Egyptian Government, acting on his advice, had sold the Daira Sanieh for £6,250,000 to Sir Ernest Cassel and a group of capitalists. The appointment of Sir Elwin Palmer to the governorship of the National Bank, coinciding with the disposal of the Daira Sanieh, caused some comment, especially when it was reported that the Government had in their possession a report of Crookshank Pacha, which declare I that the Daira was worth at the lowest com- putation £10,000,000. This subject has been revived in a recent work on Egypt and Harari Pacha made the following declaration to the author in regard to Sir Elwin’s share in the matter. In justice to the memory of Sir Elwin we will reproduce what Harari Pacha said on the subject of the Daira deal :— The Financial Advisers have never made use of their position for their personal profit never, and Sir E. Palmer is the last man in the world to do so. Only he left the Government service to take up a brilliant position ; hence the trouble. Palmer was poor, why should he refuse such a good berth? As to making him self responsible for the sale of the Daira, the

thing is ridiculous, for, powerful as the Finan- cial Adviser may be, he can do nothing with- out, on the one hand, the approval of the Council of Ministers, and on the other, that of Lord Cromer. The idea that Lord Cromer would allow any suspicious deal whatever is so absolutely impossible that one does not stop even to consider it. The truth of the matter is, that the thing was done with the complete ap- proval of all the members of the Government Egyptian and English. No one could foresee that the estate would increase in value to such an extent, and in so short a space of time. £6 2'0,000 was considered a very good price for the Daira,’ and, besides, the buyer said, ‘I relieve you of all the trouble, all the anxiety all the expense which the estate has brought you. On my part I shall do the best I can for myself, and if at the finish of the business there is a profit, we shall share equally in it.’ It must be admitted that the offer seemed a good one, and one cannot blame the Adviser who recommended it and had it approved by the Ministers.” Mr. Raphael Suares, the well-known banker, has corroborated Harari Pacha’s statements that Sir Elwin had no arrangement with Sir Ernest Cassel. To the same author, here marked : —‘‘The thing won’t hold water,” and I can prove it. It was I, and not Cassel whom I had only seen once in my life and with whom I had had no business relations—it was I, I re- peat, who obtained, first, the concession for the founding of the National Bank and the option of purchasing the‘Daira’ for £6,0 0,000. Our house, Suares Brothers, not wishing to supply all the capital necessary, I left for London with the intention of offering a share in the business to one of my friends. On the boat, Mr. D., well-known in Egypt, advised me to immediately see Cassel, who, he believed, was anxious to enter into business relations with Egypt. I took his advice. When I offered 50 per cent. of the ‘Daira’ to Cassel he said: ‘I know nothing about this class of business, what do yon think it ought to yield ? I told him I looked for a profit of something over £1,000 000, when he said be would trust to me ; and the affair was concluded. The concession for the Bank seemed to please him more and he asked who should place at the head. It was then that I proposed Palmer, whose name, so well known as Financial Adviser, was bound to carry weight. You will see, therefore, that there was absolutely no arrangement between Sir E. Cassel and Sir E. Palmer.” It must be confessed that Sir Elwin was a very lucky man, and in both the high official posts which he occupied in the Egyptian Government the pioneer work had been under- taken by his predecessors. The Director-Generalship of Accounts was his first office in Egypt, which Sir Gerald Fitz- gerald had occupied from 1877 to 1885. Lord Cromer remarked in the recent Report, “Of the many Englishmen, who, by steady and unosten- tations work, hare rendered good service to the cause of Egyptian reform, there are few to whom greater merit con be assigned than Sir Gerald Fitzgerald, who first took this difficult task in hand, and who, by dint of untiring industry and perseverance, overcame all the obstacles which had to be encountered. Sir Gerald Fitzgerald did not take much part in the reforms themselves, but he performed work which was indispensable to others if the reforms were to be carried out.” During the years 1885- 1889 in which Sir Elwin occupied the post he was enabled to initiate those reforms which the industry of his predecessor had made possible, and the same luck fell to him when he was called upon to occupy the post of Financial Adviser. During the six years of his predecessor’s. Sir Edgar Vincent’s, administra- tion, the seed was sown and was steadily ripening- which under Sir Elwin Palmer and his successor yielded a bountiful harvest. “In many cases,” Lord Milner declares in his monu- mental work on Egypt “the reforms, which have borne the richest fruit, were due directly to Vincent’s initiative,” and he elsewhere re- marks that “Vincent will always be remembered as the most gifted and one of the most ener- getic of the little band of Englishmen who, under the presiding genius of Baring, rescued the finances by restoring the prosperity of Egypt.” Sir Elwin for the second time found his path made easy for him. He was as lucky in his career as a banker as he was as an official, for the National Bank was launched at the psycho- logical moment and was bound to be a success, as was the Agricultural Bank, of which he was chosen President in 1902. Besides his banking duties ha was greatly interested in many local companies of various sorts. He appears to have been esteemed by his fellow-directors for his shrewdness and business like capacities, and owing to the success of the many concerns he was interested in he was able to accumulate a large fortune in the few years that have followed his retirement from the post of Financial Adviser. Of all the Anglo-Egyptians who have benefited by the progress of Egypt, Sir Elwin was the foremost so far as wealth is concerned, and he must have left a very considerable estate. He could not be termed a popular man, and some of his business methods have been the subject of much criticism. Whether he administered the National Bank with that scrupulous regard for financial "tone,” such as should characterise the conduct of a great State Bank, it is not for us to decide. Criticism is very easy in Egypt and it is only natural that such a successful man as Sir Elwin was should have some enemies. But nothing succeeds like success, and nobody will venture to dispute that Sir Ernest Cassel made a wise choice when he selected Sir Elwin Palmer to guide the fortunes of the great banking institution which he has directed with such signal success. The operations on the Bourse this morning began as usual at 10 o’clock, when the Presi- dent of the Corbeille, Mr. D. Caralli, pro- nounced an eloquent discourse on the late banker and proposed that business should be suspended for half an hour as a sign of respect for his memory.

The salary of the Governor of the National Bank is £5,000 a year with residence equi- talent to a rental allowance of £1,000 a year. There are also many other perquisites such as a box at the opera, etc. Sir Elwin was insured in the New York Life Insurance Company for £2,000. The insurance was a 20 years endowment policy, expiring in next July. The National Bank of Egypt both at Cairo and Alexandria was closed to-day. The other Cairo banks will close this afternoon at 3 o’clock. There will be a memorial service this after- noon at All Saints’ Church, Cairo. The body is to be embalmed and taken to England. Among the orders, which the late financier received were the Grand Cordons of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh. Sir Elwin belonged to the St. James’s Club in London. His recreations, as given in “Who’s Who” for 1906, are limited to golf and cycling.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: El Kaimakam Savile Bey, Senior Inspector of the Kassala Province, has been granted leave till April 26. El Bimbashi Blomfield, 1st Battalion, has been granted leave of absence until March 15. El Bimhashi Bridge, 11th Sudanese, resumed duty yesterday. The following officers have passed the intermediate Arabic examination: El Miralai Wilson Bey, Governor,. Sennar Province ; El Kaimakam Leigh, Bey, D.S.O., Acting Officer Commanding 4th Battalion ; El Kaimakam Rawson Bey, Acting Officer Commanding, 1 th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi Drake, Deputy Assis- tant Adjutant General ; El Bimbashi Parsons, Department of Supplies ; El Bimbashi Arden, 4th Battalion ; El Bimbashi Brakenridge, Medical Corps ; El Bimbashi Mayne, D.S.O. 13th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi Wise, 1st Batta- lion ; El Bimbashi Rome, Cavalry ; El Bim- bashi Hughes, Medical Corps. Captain C. C. Maud, D.S.O., Somersetshire Light Infantry, who has arrived in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, and has been posted to the 11th Sudanese with the rank of Bimbashi. Lieutenant P. A Wilson, West India Regi- ment, is similarly taker on the strength of the Egyptian Army and posted to the 11th Sudanese with the rank of Bimbashi. El Kalmakam J. H. Rivers Bey, Medical Corpe, has resigned his commission in the Egyptian Army.

div.head: SUDAN NOTES
div.p: Things are very quiet here at present, as most of the officers, both civil and military, are out in their various districts collecting taxes. etc. There is no polo going on, am afraid we shall not he able to play again until March or April, when some of the officers return here from their districts. We are having beautifully cool weather now, and the climate here at this time of year is quite perfect.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD.
div.p: The new board of this company is now com- posed of Messre, L. Carton de Wiart, Adolphe Cattani, Montagu Summers, F.Z.S., F R G.S., J. E. Drower, W. A. Loning, and Mr. Con- stantine Meimarachi, the managing director. In regard to the acquisition of the new site for this company’s business in Cairo, we think it our duty to note a remarkable example of the altruistic character of Mr. Constantine Meimarachi’s dealings. This gentleman lately purchased a site at the junction of Charia El Manakh and Charia El Madabegh, in the Ismailieh quarter of Cairo, at the price of L.E. 72,247. The property is of an area of 4816.5 square metres, of a rectangular shape, and through its central position in the Euro- pean business and residential quarter, it un- undoubtedly provides one of the finest and most suitable sites in Cairo for the erection of the new buildings. According to the report of Mr. Henry Hinks (Messrs. Barclay Hinks & Co., Cairo), a member of the Surveyors Institn- tion, London, dated the 16th January, 1906 the present value of this property is L.E. 96,330, or £20 per square metre. Now this property was bought by Mr. Meimarachi in his own name and he could, if he so wished, have disposed of it to the company at a profit to himself of £18 000. But he refused to take advantage of this and with a noble disinte restedness, which is very rare in Egypt, he has disposed of it to the company without a mil- lieme profit to himself. Such actions deserve to be noted when they occur as an example of high financial rectitude, and we take great pleasure in making the Egyptian public ac- quainted with Mr. Meimarachi’s altruism.

div.head: Isherwood’s Cairo Cigarettes.
div.p: The reputation which these Cigarettes have gained in the past, stands unrivalled to-day, because it is well-known that constan care and attention is devoted to supplyingtreally first class cigarettes only. Between the British Consulate and Turf Club.

div.head: MOERIS HOTEL,
div.p: First Class Encampment On Lake Moeris In connection with the Karoon Hotel Fayoum. For particulars apply Mr. TASCO, Fayoum. 26843-31-8-3-906

div.head: NILE-RED SEA RAILWAY.
SPEECHES TO THE NATIVES
BENEFITS OF THE NEW RAILWAY.
div.p: The excellent speech delivered by Lord Cromer was translated into Hadendowa for the benefit of the large crowds of natives present by the Commandant of Police, and was received with cheers. Slatin Pacha’s speech to the natives con- tained the following passages : "I do not think any one of you is ignorant of the benefits to be derived from this railway which has now been established between here and Khartoum, especially you merchants, who can perfectly realise that to facilitate communications will entail much progress in trade. The success that will be attained by Suakin and Port Sudan will open more markets and increase the trade in both towns and will give the Arabs a good opportunity to sell their animals, batter, and milk at good prices.” Slatin Pacha also pointed out the openings there would be for labour and said that camel owners could use their camels for agricultural transport as in Egypt. The peroration to Slatin Pacha’s speech was as follows : The Government cannot offer you fortune, but guards your property and will protect you from aggression. The acquirement of wealth depends on your ability and activity. May God enlighten you and increase the fruits of prosperity and progress. You must believe in the Government’s good intentions and all its endeavours for your welfare. It is your duty to wish long life to Lord Cromer and the Governor-General, who are responsible for the administration of the country and ask God to guide them to do good and benefit the Sudan.
Visit to the Harbour.

After the inaugural ceremony had been concluded, a visit was paid to the works going on in the harbour. Lord Cromer, accompanied by the Governor-General, Sir Vincent Corbett, Sir Randolf von Slatin, Inspector General, Captain Phipps-Hornby, R. N., Colonel Mao- Cracken, Commanding 2nd Bn. R. Berkshire Regt., Major Hawker, Governor Red Sea Province. Captain Kennedy R. E., Director of Works, Mr. Higgins and Lieut. Kelly R. E., Resident Engineer, Port Sudan, were conveyed by the narrow gauge railway along the eastern arm of the harbour to inspect the works, as far as the temporary quays. At the landing stage of the temporary quay, Lord Cromer and party were conveyed across the harbour to the western side. From here Lord Cromer, the Governor General, Sir Kennedy, R. E, and Lieut. Kelly, R. E. wre conveyed by motor-car along the harbour to the Point, and then to visit the walls, return- ing via the hospital, and en route visiting the town, to the Mess Buildings. Afterwards the party returned to the landing stage, and went round the harbour, visiting the south-west arm, skirting the quarantine pro montory, thence to the special landing stage, Picket boats of H.M.S. Diana were in readi- ness, the leading boat conveying Lord Cromer, the Governor General, Sir Vincent Corbett, Captain Phipps Hornby, R.N., Captain Ken- nedy, R.E., and Major Hawker. On disembark- ing, Lord Cromer and party rejoined the train, and returned to the station enclosure. The impression formed after the visit was that Port Sudan was the cleanest and best laid out town on the Red Sea, and that the progress which has been achieved here during the last nine months is simply amazing. Lord Cromer, accompained by the Governor General and the other members of the party, on reaching the station, took train for Suakin the Egyptian Artillery firing a salute of 21 guns as the train lift the station. The British guard of honour and the officer in command returned to Khartoum by the same train.

div.head: Arrival at Suakin.
div.p: I have just arrived at Suakin and am leaving at 1.45 for Khartoum where I expect to arrive at midday to-morrow. Lord Cromer, on arriving here, made an inspection of the condensors and afterwards inspected the harbour on board the launch Pioneer. His lordship afterwards left for the Atbara. He will spend the night at Gebeit.

div.head: Arrival at Atbara.
div.p: I have just arrived at Atbara after a most interesting journey. I expect to arrive at Khartoum about 5 p.m. Lord Cromer arrives at Khartoum to-morrow. His lordship visited Sinkat, the scene of Tewfik Bay’s gallant defence in 1884, and slept at Gebeit. At Suakin yesterday I was officially in- formed that the Abou Hamed-Kareim v line had been completed. The Press party have been throughout splendidly treated, and thanks are especially due to Kaimakhm Owen Bey for his unfailing kindness and energy on our behalf.

div.head: OPINION OF LONDON PRESS.
div.p: All the London papers to-day contain enlo- gistic articles regarding Lord Cromer, in con- nection with the opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway, and are full of appreciation of the work accomplished by Colonel Macaulay, con- trasting the state of affairs in D 85 and in 1906. They point to the moral triumphs achieved end look upon the Berber Railway as one of the wonders of the modem world.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. Machell’s brother-in-law, Count Glei- chen, who celebrated his forty-third birthday last week, is shortly leaving Berlin, where he is Military Attache at the British Embassy, an appointment he has held some time, and is going to Washington in the same capacity. Count Gleichen is a cousin of our King, and his godson, hearing the same name, Albert Edward. He is a keen soldier, has seen much good service, and is a successful author, his best known works being "With the Camel Corps up the Nile” and "With the Mission to Menelik.”

Mr. MacMillan, the American millionaire, who has been such a frequent visitor of late to Egypt, is now living in British East Africa at the Juga farm, where he has all the comforts of his Mayfair home. Mr. MacMillan’s farm, which is at Donya Sabok, comprises all that the word "Ideal” implies. The electric light, coupled with an ice plant, and luxuries that only a great city affords, have been brought to the gate of the greatest game-shooting field in the world. We are asked to state that, owing to Sir Elwin Palmer’s death, Mrs. Dickson’s dance at the National Bank on February 7 will not take place.

When the Leicestershires were quartered at Alexandria there was no more popular officer than Captain the Hon. Harold Brooke Hawke. The many friends he left in Egypt will therefore he interested to learn of his engagement to Anne, widow of Arthur J. J. Bamford, of Misterton, Leicestershire.

The Chairman of the Daira Sanieh Company is unfortunate in losing Bast Bradford, and we venture to think East Bradford is unfortu- nate in losing him. Sir Vincent Caillard is a distinguished financier and clever business man, and his presence in the House could scarcely have resulted in anything but good.

Sir Vincent is also Chairman of the London agency of the National Bank of Egypt and has been a good deal besides, since the 23rd of October, 1856. Then he was born, the son of a judge, and a good judve, too, who married the daughter of Lord Besoonfield's first cousin, and sent the son of the marriage to Etom, and "The Shop."

"The Shop" turned out a Pollock Gold Medallist, who, thirty-one years ago, got his commission in the Royal Engineers. Other commissions, however, proved more attractive, and Sir Vincent sat upon a good many of mese. Then he took a torn with the Intelli- gence Department daring the Egyptian Cam- paign of 1882, the result of which was that the Ottoman Public Debt Council acquired a President, in 1883, and England, Holland and Belgium a financial representative at "Cons- tant.”

From that onerous office Sir Vincent retired five or six years ago with all the honours and some other medals, and the Grand Cordons of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh. Intermediat- ely, he has been of the brotherhood of the pen; and has written articles for other people’s news-papers and reviews.

div.head: PEACE OF THE WORLD.
FRANCE AND GERMANY’S
PROTESTATIONS.
div.p: The President of the Reichstag eulogised the Emperor, whose ambition since his acces- sion had been to maintain the peace. He added that a powerful army would be able to over- throw whoever inconsiderately disturbed the peace of the world. (Havas)
M. Etienne, on unveiling the monument to the aeronauts of the siege of Paris, stated that France was more than ever pacific, but in any ease French peace was dignified and strong. (Havas)

div.head: MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
PEACEFUL OUTLOOK.
div.p: The delegates of the Powers, and notably M. Revoil, paid visits to Herr von Radowitz on the occasion of the Emperor William’s birth day. (Havas)
At the banquet given on the Emperor Wil- liam’s birthday, Prince von Radolin said that the Morocco Conference would end in satis- factory results. (Havas)

div.head: THE CRETAN IMBROGLIO.
ITALIANS SEIZE CUSTOMS.
div.p: The Italians have demanded an indemnity for the murder of the soldier killed on the 18th inst., and in consequence of the refusal of the Cretan Government to pay, they have seised three custom houses as a guarautee. (Reuter)

div.head: SPANISH ROYAL MARRIAGE.
A FAMILY GATHERING.
div.p: King Alfonso and the Princess Ena are motoring daily together. (Reuter)
A general family gathering will take place here to-day, at which the Princess Ena will be presented to her future mother-in-law. (Reuter)

div.head: MUTINY AT VLADIVOSTOK.
ATTACK ON COMMANDANT.
div.p: On the 22nd inst. mutinous sailors seized rifles and ammunition. On the 23rd they marched to the commandant’s house and de- manded the release of prisoners. They were dispersed with quick-firers. On the 24th the insurgent artillerymen opened fire on the com- mandant with quick-firers and rifles, wounding him in the neck and chest. (Reuter)

div.head: THE ELECTIONS.
div.p: 882 Liberals, 42 Labourites, 153 Unionists, and 84 Nationalists have been elected. (R.)

div.head: ENGLISHMAN’S ARREST IN RUSSIA.
div.p: Mr. Davison, the manager of the Cotton Mills at Yarowalav, who was arrested on the charge of possessing literature of a liberal ten- dency, has been released. (Reuter)

div.head: JAPAN’S ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: A report submitted to the Diet places the expenditure of the Army at £99,000,000, and that for the Navy at £18,000,000. (Reuter)

div.head: KARATHBODORY PACHA DEAD.
div.p: Karatheodory Pacha is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: The feature of the Egyptian Mining market on the London Stock Exchange is a Bearsqneeze which appears to have occurred in Nile Valley shares. Heavy selling earlier in the week, aided by anticipations that the company may have to go through the throes of reconstruc- tion, brought the shares down to about 5s. But on Saturday week a distinct change came over the scone. The attempt to take in shares in connection with the settlement sufficed to show that they were in exceedingly short sup- ply, for the moment at any rate, and the price left off at about 9s., rising about 50 per cent during the morning as a result of the scramble to obtain them. The North Nile Valley is to suspend opera- tions until the Nile Valley mine at Um Garaiat is further developed. The directors of the former company, whose property is only a short distance away from Um Garaiat, intend to be guided by the results obtained at depth in the Nile Valley—a cautions and no doubt a wise policy. The secretary of the Nile Valley has issued a circular stating that it is hoped to hold the annual meeting this month, and adding that temporary arrangements have been made for providing the company with funds. In the report of the engineers mention is made of the lack of labour, owing to the religious festivals, but hope is expressed that a fall complement of workers will very shortly be again available.

div.head: VIOLIN RECITAL.
div.p: Many people flocked to Signor Arrigo Serato’s violin recital, which took place at the Savoy Hotel on Friday afternoon after having been postponed from Wednesday evening. As usual there was an extraordinary small percen- tage of English among the audience, and we regret to say that some of these seemed to have mistaken the object of the entertainment, for they chatted unconcernedly to each other through several of the items. A certain amount of disappointment was felt at the announce- ment that the orchestral accompaniment was not available, as advertised, bat this feeling speedily wore off after Mme. M. Malateata had taken her place at the piano. She is a perfor- mer of no little note and her power of touch and brilliancy of execution are rare in a woman, while as an accompanist she keeps in most perfect sympathy with her partner. It was the first of Signor Serato’s concerts this season, but he made known his name in Cairo last year and the audience showed by the warmth of their greeting what pleasant recollections they held of his previous appear- ances. It was an infinite pleasure to listen to this great violinist. He succeeded in drawing a beautiful tone from his violin, his renderings were without exception fall of feeling, and the certainty of his bowing and accomplished technique excited general admiration. Signor Serato is certainly one of the greatest violinists of the present day and it must always be a pleasure to listen to him. His great qualities were especially evident in the concerto of Weiniawsky, the Perpetunm Mobile of Ries, and Jarnefeld’s Berceuse, and on the conclusion of Bach’s air on the fourth string he was accorded a perfect ovation, so enraptured was his audience. The whole concert was indeed a great success and we hope we shall hear Signor Serato several times more this season.

div.head: PRE-EMPTION.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.
div.p: Sir,—Your correspondent “Capitalist” does not seem to consider the position which his proposal would create. The object intended to be secured by the law of preemption was what the English call the “amenities” of the property, the privacy consonant with the Moslem custom of secluding? women and like- wise of getting rid of an obnoxious neighbour by buying him out. Now suppose that two Europeans or a native and a European have contracted for the sale of property and that the would-be pre emptor is a native, according to the proposal of "Capitalist” the native would be excluded from exercising his right. Can “Capitalist” or anyone else tell me why in the name of reason or equity the native pre-emptor should be debarred from the exer- cise of this right, because one of the parties to the contract happens to be a European ? If I might be allowed to offer a suggestion I think that the difficulties raised by “Capital- ist” can be got over, as they very often are, by patting in the contract of sale, and there- fore on the register, so high a price as would preclude pre emption, which, it must be re- membered, has to be exercised within six months from date of sale. This practice would, in such case, be of benefit to the Treasury and cannot in any sense be considered as “contra bonos mores,” seeing that, firstly, the parties to the sale do not guarantee the accuracy of the statement as to price, nor has in reality anybody a right to enquire what was the arrangement between two private in- dividuals. Seeing that the Government has reduced the tax on registration from five to two per cent, the extra payment involved in the pretended increase of price would fall but lightly on the purchaser and can be regarded in the nature of an insurance.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIGARETTES.
THE YEAR’S EXPORTS.
div.p: The export of Egyptian cigarettes during the past year shows a decided increase over the previous year. In 1995 Egypt exported cigarettes to the amount of kilos 702,813 as against 620,470 in 1904, an increase of kilos 82,337. This is not, however, the same rate of increase as was the total for 1901 over 1903. when there was an increase of nearly 90,000 kilos over the latter year's exports. Germany was Egypt’s biggest customer in 1905, taking kilos 864,645, an increase of kilos 59,604. England came next with kilos 93,485, am increase of only kilos 1,715. Iu fact, England’s consumption of Egyptian cigarettes remains almost stationary and by a carious coincidence the amount she took last year corresponded exactly to a kilo with what she received in 1904, viz., kilos 96,485. The next largest customer was British India and England’s other Eastern possessions, which took kilos 74,364, then Austria-Hungary with kilos 50,998, China and the Far East with kilos 25,054, and France with kilos 22,718.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S ROADS.
WHY ARE THEY “UP” ?
div.p: We should like to know why the roads are continually “up” in Alexandria. The thorough- fares seem to be either in a continual state of repair by the Municipality or else left to the devices of the Water Company, the Gas Company, the Telephone Company “et hoc genosomne.” Why cannot the repairs be under- taken during the slack season of the year ? In Cairo, we understand, and in all the chief European cities the roads are only allowed to be “up” in the off-season, after which a close time is fixed. But at Alexandria the Municipa- lity appears to have no fixed rule in regard to this. That result is that traffic is continually impeded and the various companies are allowed to do what they please in laying water mains or gas pipes. Another point which we would like to draw attention to, is the bad habit of sweeping big streets with big brooms between the hours of 1 and 2.30 p.m. The consequence is that pedestrians going home to lunch are smothered in dust without any visible im- provements to the cleanliness of the streets, for this method of sweeping only displaces the dust without removing it. In connection with streets being "up” a story is told of the present German Emperor which shows what can be done in similar circum- stances. His Majesty was prevented the year before last from passing along the Unter den Linden because the street was “up,” and he, being not at all pleased with the fact, called the responsible authorities to him, and demanded to know when the work would be finished. He was told that it could not pos- sibly be done under five or six weeks. The Kaiser said nothing, bat when he drove back to his palace he sent for the General commanding the district, and the next morn- ing a corps of military engineers was at work, with the result that the whole thing was finished within twenty four hours. We only wish we had some authority here with the power to wake up in the same way the Municipality.

div.head: A RETROSPECT.
div.p: The opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway recalls one of the biggest and most expensive blunders ever made by a Government Depart- ment. The railway was first planned by the British War Office authorities as an aid to Lord Wolseley's advance in the cause of the Gordon Relief Expedition. The material was prepared in England and shipped to Suakin by the old Indian transports Orontes and Serapis, hot after lying for a long time at the Red Sea port, it was re-shipped to England, and for the space of nearly twenty years the greater part of it lay in the Gillingham extension of Chatham Dockyard. An observant Admiralty official “discovered” it some two years ago, and that portion of it—rails, sleepers, etc.— which remained serviceable was sent out to Egypt, and has been employed in the construction of the line.

div.head: EXHIBITION OF ENGLISH FURNITURE
div.p: “A place for everything and everything in its place” is an old English proverb, and to this, together with the refined tastes of our ladies of the household, is due the many and useful articles of furniture without which to day no salon or drawing-room or dining-room is complete. To possess dainty, handsome, and withal useful articles of furniture is the delight of the mistress of any home who knows well how to create that undefined charm which causes mere men to say, “Well, a lady has been arranging here.” But a lady of the most refined tastes is dependent, after all, upon the maker of the things she loves and knows how to use so well. Now at the Salon Zarani, in the rue de la gare do Caire, there is an exhibition of articles of furniture that would charm the hearts of our ladies of the household. Messrs. Davies Bryan & Co. are to be congratulated on the interesting and well-designed and wrought collection of English furniture, an exhibition of which they opened on Saturday. The various pieces of furniture, such as charming ca- binets with their doors glazed in lead of graceful patterns, the well finished and exceedingly useful writing tables, the dainty chairs, the comfortable leather-covered couches and easy chairs - chairs that are really easy and a pleasure to sit in, the wardrobes—a delight to the ladies, in that they are supplied with useful fittings for the safe keeping of the wondrous mysteries of a lady's robes, and the looking glasses (to use the old-fashioned English term) and fit- tings for bed and dressing rooms have but to be seen to be admired as only chastely wrought furniture can be, and being admired they must also be desired. Then, there are. the sideboards in solid mahogany, all well wrought with drawers and doors which it is a pleasure to open; and the mantel pieces— the recent coldness in Alexan dria is a sufficient warrant for the appreciate of this, an inseparable fifting of a British home. We advise our readers to see for themselves and we feel sure that having seen they will desire to possess some those charming pieces of furniture in the Sherraton, Renaissance and modern English styles.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: The warmer weather is drawing many people out to Ghezireh Palace with its beautiful gardens and splendid air, and the hotel is now as full as it can be. There are rumours alterations to be effected in the building before tie next season, for it is undoubtedly the most popular resort in the neighbourhood after the winter has past. The dance given at the hotel last Thursday night was the second within the week, the officers of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers having entertained many of their friends there previous Tuesday night. Over 170 people dined in the restaurant the latter evening, among the hosts being the Count and Countess Lerche, Lord and Lady Talbot of Malahide, Lady Lampson, Major and Mrs. Byrom, Major and Mrs. Parvis, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Vicars, Mr. and Mrs. George Pauling, Mr. and Mrs. Rom, Mr. and Mrs. Wall, Mrs. Hardy and her son, Capt. Hardy, Mrs. Cardey and Miss Andrew. The Tzigane orchestra played during dinner and also during the hour given over to supper, and its seductive strains kept people dancing till the small hours. Many the Ghezireh residents were present and a fair number arrived from the Savoy, and as usual there were many officers present. The Countess Lerche was among the dancers, and her beautiful dress of white satin with lightly spangled flounces and draperies was much admired. Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley, who had been dining with Capt. and Mrs. Hardy, were there, and of the same party were Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish. Mrs. Douglas Vicars was looking' extremely well in a lovely lace robe with touches of black velvet at the elbows and neck, and a brilliant ornament in her hair. Mrs. York brought her daughters, one silver grey satin son pie trimmed with wreaths of palest pink chiffon roses, and the other in white satin with trimming and slippers of gold tissue. Mrs. Whittaker, in black showered over with gold spangles, was chape- roning Miss Whittaker, also in black but with rose in her hair. Mrs. Armstrong, who was wearing a handsome gown of velvet, brought with her Miss Boulter, who is one of our latest arrivals, and Mrs. Valentine Smith, also in velvet, was escorted by her niece, Mrs. Am- bridge, Mrs. Allen Joseph had brought her party, Miss Joseph in a very dainty late frock And Miss Ing in pink silk. Dr. and Mrs. Nolan from Zeitoun were there, the latter wearing a handsome pompadeur silk of light colouring with touches of pink about it Mrs. Rom was in white, and Miss Begg’s frock of pale pink was just an ideal length for dancing purposes. Dr. and Mrs. Phillips brought Miss Phillips with them, the latter looking delightfully early Victorian with her hair parted and knotted low, and her black edged flounced skirt of potted muslin. Report says she is one of the best dancers of the season, and she is greatly in request. Miss de Belinski was in cream satin with embroidered appliques of light colouring, and Mrs. Wall was in rose coloured silk with lace emplacement. Among the other dancers were noticed Capt. and Mrs. Rome, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, the Misses Coles, Miss Lampson, Col. Watson, Major Davidson, Lieut. Adams, Lieut. Caningham Lieut. Robertson, Lieut. Palmer, Mr. Dickin- son, the Messrs. Bennet, and Mr. Rule.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday changed to cooler conditions. Fresh gales prevailed throughout the day, with spells of rain. The force of anemometer reached 90 kil. To-day the weather pro- mises to be better. The barometer is rising.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
THEATRE ZIZINIA
PHEDRE
div.p: L’amour incestueux qae Phèdre, d’aprè) li mythologie, uourriHsait pour Hyppolyte, fils de sod mari, est an sajet qa’ont abordé ear la scène trois poètes différents : Euripide, Sénèque et Racine. Avant hier soir on donnait la pièoe de Roin 11 serait superflu d’énumérer ici toutes les qualités de cette sublime tragédie que tout la monde connaît, pour l’avoir lue. Phèdre,comme ohof d’œuvre, ne vient qu’après Athalie, mai i elle est de toutes les œ ivres de Racine la plus vigoureuse. Les rôles de femmes en particulier sont tou ce qu’ôn peut créer de mieux. Les passions de l’amour dont brûle Phèdre sont peintes avec grâce et hardiesse. Ce sont là des pièces qu’on ne sait plus écrire, ni représenter aujourd’hui. 11 n’est donné qu’a quelques artistes de génie et remarquablement doués, d’interpréter oomme il oonvient les chefs- d’œuvre du théâtre olassique. Mme Moreno eit de o nombre. E le nous a procuré de fortes émotions dans ce rôle si difficile de Phèdre. Elle est une des meilleure artiste) de notre époque et les Alexandrins doivent s’estimer heureux de l’avoir possédée durant toate la saison. Mme Eaylat dans le rôle d’Arioie a été très admirée pour l’élégance et la pareté de sa diction.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Au jour d hui à midi s1 demie)
div.p: La oote est soatenne, mais le) transactions restent limitées aux National Bank, Banque d’Athènes et Sait and Soda. Eu National, le cours de l’action anoienne remonte de 25 11/16 à 25 13/16 et oelui de la nouvelle de 24 13/i6 à 24 15/16 acheteurs, avec une grande activité. Des ordres de vente de S Ut and Soda sont venues du Caire, o qui a fait fléchir le titre de 91/9 à 21/6. On a échangé également quelq ues Estâtes à 1 11/16. Quant aax Banques d’Athènes,il s’est dessiné ce matin un fort mouvement à la hausse. De 183 1/2 le prix est remonté à 135 1/4 ache tours, en excellente tendance. La Cassa di Soonto hausse à 2Ô6 l’ancienne et à 203 la noavelle, le Trust à 1 7/32. et le? Markets à 23/9. Eu revanche la Banque d’Abyssinie tomba à 6 11/16, 1’Anglo American Nile à 5 11/16 et la Delta Light à 11 3/8. L’Urbaine est soutenue à 5 9/32 acheteurs.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: jua uassa ai ooonto naasse a zoo l ancienne et à 203 la nouvelle, le Trust à 1 7/32, et les Markets à 23/9. Eu revanche la Banque d’Abyssinie tomba à 6 11/16, Y Anglo American Nile à 5 11/16 eh la Delta Light à 11 3/8. L’Urbaine est soutenue à 5 9/32 aohateure. d’nn administrateur de la Port Said Salt, qu: refuserait d’accepter les conditions d’échangi proposées, soit une action Sait and Soda oontn deux actions Port Said Salt. Cet administra teur alléguerait qu’on ne saurait donner deu> actions valant, à ses yeux, 28 A., o’est-àdin 14nh. l’une, contre une aotion de 22di. Voilà, à en oroire certaines versions, pour qnoi l’on aurait essayé, ces jours derniers, d. pousser le cours de la Sait and Soda, qui, sans les ventes intervenues, serait probablement h 25 ou 26 sh. Nous recevons d’Alexandrie quelques ren- seignements complémentaires intéressants la mrohe des affaires de la Splendid Hotels of Egypt Co. Lestrvvaux d’agrandissement da New Khé- divial Hotel avanoeut rapidement Ainsi que nous l’avons déjà dit, le rez de-chaussée est occupé depuis donze jours. Le premier étage est à peu près meublé ; il sera ouvert landi prochain. Les deux autres étages seront amé- nagés le 15 Mars au plus tard. Eu oes quinze derniers jours, on a dû refuser environ 200 personnes, et si les 150 nonvelles chambres étaient prêtes elles seraient tontes loaées. Eaattendant.il ressort de l’état oomparatif des recettes que, du 1er au 24 Janvier courant, il y a ea une augmentation de P.E. 53,266 sar fa période correspondante de l’aonée dernière. Les cours des ootons arrivent en baisse d'A- mérique. Le disponible a perdu 10 points, le Mai 18 et l’Octobre 9. Les arrivages ont été de 23,000 balles oontre 41,000. Le marché de Liverpool est pins ou moins stationnaire. Ici, le Mare a ouvert, oa matin, à 16 9/32 pour olôturer à 16 13/32. MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l’exéaation de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Braxelles, An- vers, Liverpool et New York. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompany- ing description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to do considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.

div.p: This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little wanner than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uni- formly warm than many other places in Europe Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time oc- cupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio- Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alex- andria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charm- ing and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days. NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steam- ers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri. From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here. Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte- rest, whilst the local promenades and excur- sions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks m Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that te Vallom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog- wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).-The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer. The patriarchal home of Italy’s most an- eient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medie- val churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the in- comparable Campo Santo filled with its won- derful tombs. From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail. MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of ' the Bible. The public gardons and the monu- mental cemetery are also worth a visit. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAG- GIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

They are as follows :— The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton,London or Liverpool— occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows :— Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi 3 days Alexandria to Messina....... Port Said or A lexandria to Marsei 1 les Alexandria toVenice and Trieste... Alexandria to Naples............ Port Said to Genoa.............. Port Said to Naples ............ Alexandria to Constantinople ... Alexandria to Pineus ........... Port Said to Gibraltar..........

The steamers, of the P. & O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt. As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours. The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. & O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria. As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris” and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea- port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Cam- paniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by tram by way of Monza : Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot ; then come Tremezzo, Cadennbbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and- three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as “A cluster of delights and grandeurs.” LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a populatien of 10,000 people and is charm- ingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interest- ing paintings, “Entombment,” by Ciseri, and “The Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion. LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Lake Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgen- stock and Sommenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn. THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTER- LAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Gietsbaeh, Trummelbach and Staubback. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed. CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alex- andria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to he present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the “Ferry boats,” having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England yo will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.
